verses.text: When all the kings who were beyond the Jordan, in the hill country, in the lowland, on the whole coast of the Great Sea near Lebanon—the Hittite, the Amorite, the Canaanite, the Perizzite, the Hivite, and the Jebusite—heard of this,
verses.comment: Maintains word order; 'the Great Sea' refers to the Mediterranean Sea.

verses.text: they gathered together with one purpose to fight against Joshua and Israel.
verses.comment: 'With one purpose' renders the Hebrew idiom 'with one mouth'.

verses.text: But when the inhabitants of Gibeon heard what Joshua had done to Jericho and to Ai,
verses.comment: No major changes.

verses.text: they acted with cunning, and went and prepared provisions, and took worn-out sacks for their donkeys, wine skins worn-out and torn and mended,
verses.comment: 'Acted with cunning' literally 'acted craftily.'

verses.text: and wore old, patched sandals on their feet and old garments on themselves. And all their bread was dry and crumbly.
verses.comment: Bread described as 'dry and crumbly' matches the sense of 'moldy.'

verses.text: They went to Joshua in the camp at Gilgal and said to him and to the men of Israel, 'We have come from a distant country. Now therefore, make a covenant with us.'
verses.comment: 'Make a covenant' is literal; 'men of Israel' as in the Hebrew.

verses.text: But the men of Israel said to the Hivites, 'Perhaps you live among us. Then how could we make a covenant with you?'
verses.comment: Direct address clarified by 'the Hivites' as in Hebrew.

verses.text: They said to Joshua, 'We are your servants.' But Joshua said to them, 'Who are you? And where do you come from?'
verses.comment: 'We are your servants' is a customary phrase for requesting peace.

verses.text: They said to him, 'From a very distant country your servants have come, because of the name of the LORD your God. For we have heard a report of him, and all that he did in Egypt,
verses.comment: 'The name of the LORD' maintains the Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: and all that he did to the two kings of the Amorites who were beyond the Jordan, to Sihon the king of Heshbon, and to Og king of Bashan, who was at Ashtaroth.
verses.comment: 'Who was at Ashtaroth' clarifies the geographical reference.

verses.text: So our elders and all the inhabitants of our country said to us, 'Take provisions in your hand for the journey, and go to meet them and say to them, “We are your servants. Now then, make a covenant with us.”'
verses.comment: 'Provisions in your hand' is idiomatic for carrying supplies.

verses.text: Here is our bread. It was still warm when we took it from our houses as food for the journey on the day we set out to come to you, but now, see, it is dry and crumbly.
verses.comment: 'Dry and crumbly' follows the sense of the Hebrew 'moldy'.

verses.text: And these wineskins we filled were new, and see, they are torn. And these garments and sandals of ours are worn out from the very long journey.'
verses.comment: No significant changes.

verses.text: So the men took some of their provisions, but did not ask counsel from the LORD.
verses.comment: 'Did not ask counsel from the LORD' reflects the Hebrew 'did not ask the mouth of the LORD.'

verses.text: And Joshua made peace with them and made a covenant with them to let them live, and the leaders of the congregation swore an oath to them.
verses.comment: 'Congregation' is 'Israelites' in other translations, but here as in Hebrew.

verses.text: At the end of three days after they had made a covenant with them, they heard that they were their neighbors and that they lived among them.
verses.comment: 'Neighbors' is a literal translation of the Hebrew.

verses.text: The people of Israel set out and came to their cities on the third day. Now their cities were Gibeon, Chephirah, Beeroth, and Kiriath-jearim.
verses.comment: 'Set out' means 'journeyed' or 'moved out.'

verses.text: But the people of Israel did not attack them, because the leaders of the congregation had sworn to them by the LORD, the God of Israel. Then all the congregation grumbled against the leaders.
verses.comment: 'Attack them' is translated from 'struck them.'

verses.text: But all the leaders said to all the congregation, 'We have sworn to them by the LORD, the God of Israel, and now we may not touch them.'
verses.comment: 'Touch' here means 'harm.'

verses.text: This is what we will do to them: let them live, lest wrath be upon us because of the oath that we swore to them.'
verses.comment: Maintains word order.

verses.text: And the leaders said to them, 'Let them live.' So they became cutters of wood and drawers of water for all the congregation, just as the leaders had spoken to them.
verses.comment: 'Cutters of wood and drawers of water' is a literal phrase.

verses.text: Joshua summoned them and said to them, 'Why did you deceive us, saying, “We are very far from you,” when you live among us?
verses.comment: No significant changes.

verses.text: Now therefore you are cursed, and some of you will never cease being slaves, cutters of wood and drawers of water for the house of my God.'
verses.comment: 'Never cease being slaves' reflects the Hebrew idiom.

verses.text: They answered Joshua, 'Because it was told to your servants for a certainty that the LORD your God had commanded his servant Moses to give you all the land and to destroy all the inhabitants of the land from before you—so we feared greatly for our lives because of you and did this thing.
verses.comment: 'Told to your servants for a certainty' preserves the Hebrew emphatic.

verses.text: And now, look, we are in your hand. Do as it seems good and right in your eyes to do to us.'
verses.comment: Literal rendering of 'in your hand.'

verses.text: So he did this to them and delivered them out of the hand of the people of Israel, and they did not kill them.
verses.comment: 'Delivered them out of the hand' is a literal phrase.

verses.text: But Joshua made them that day, cutters of wood and drawers of water for the congregation and for the altar of the LORD, to this day, in the place that he should choose.
verses.comment: 'To this day' shows the ongoing results; 'the place he should choose' refers to God's chosen worship site.
